unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Chi-square distribution vs $t$-distribution
question_text: In what way is the chi-square distribution different from the $t$ -distribution?

choices.text: There are many chi-square distributions based on the number of degrees of freedom, but only one t t -distribution.
The chi-square distribution is used to write both confidence intervals and hypothesis tests, but the t t -distribution is only used to write hypothesis tests.
Chi-square values are always positive while t t -values can be positive or negative.
The chi-square distribution becomes more nearly normal as the degrees of freedom gets smaller while the t t -distribution becomes more nearly normal as the degrees of freedom gets larger.
For low degrees of freedom, the chi-square distribution is symmetric while the t t -distribution is skewed right.
